content.description:
Traverse left a few meters from the belay bolts and then head up the bolt line. Crux comes between bolts 2 and 3 (head right, then traverse back in left on the weakness). After that, bucket slamming brings you to the chains!

Long draw your first bolt.Â 

Far left of the Gomer ledge; the bolt line is a a few meters left of the belay bolts.
7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Great multi pitch line with the first pitch being the toughest and best quality.

P1: 5.9 - The most sustained pitch, finish at a 2 bolt anchor.
P2: 5.7 - From the P1 anchors, traverse right crossing a gully and passing above (bushwhack a little) a tree; then head straight up the low angle bucket bash, finish at a 2 bolt anchor.
P3: 5.8 - Continue straight up the bolt line, cross a mini roof obliquely to your right, and then pull the roof at the top for an exciting finish. The vast majority of this pitch is similar to its predecessor, jug hauling at on low angle terrain! Sitting belay on a 2 bolt anchor.

Getting Down:
1. Walk Off: From the top out, head climbers right (east) walking along the big ledge until you meet up with the well worn climbers trail (no need to scramble up the small cliff above the belay station). This brings you down on the East side of the cliff band, spitting you out directly across from the east staircase.
2. Rap: Not recommended, but possible as 3, single rope raps. Mind your halfway mark, and cross your fingers that your rope doesn't get stuck in the tree.

Start on the Gomer ledge, traverse the corner over to the slab wall for the next two pitches. Can walk off via the summit trail or rap down (tie an end knot)
24 bolts fixed anchors

Two pitch climb, 2nd pitch is the crux pitch, which I think should be avoided. 

P1: 5.9+ (3 stars from me!): The crux comes low down pulling the roof perhaps 3 m off the deck (bolt protected), with a second crux coming up high just below the anchors (go right, left is possible but more difficult). Enjoyable climbing!

P2: 5.10c (avoid, dirty rock, loose blocks): Climb easy terrain (4th and low 5th) on lichen covered rock (some of it is loose!) passing a few bolts until the base of the real climbing. You'll find yourself at the base of a vertical face with a series of mini-roofs, which pinches into a right facing, off vertical messy corner. Keep the bolt line (3 bolts on this steep section) over your left shoulder as you start, pull out of the corner onto the face, clip your second and third bolts, pull up under the top, larger roof and then take the airy traverse over top of your last bolt to the left before finally pulling up through the weakness in the roof to the chains. Mind the loose rock (I trundled out a cinder block sized piece after my belayer was clear), and the tick covered bush just down/left of the anchors. 

Do not link the pitches, the rope drag is horrendous and the belay at the top of P1 is comfortable. Long draw your first four bolts on P2. You cannot walk off of this one, and I would not advise belaying from the top of P2, it would be a nightmare of a hanging belay. Both pitches are less than 30 m. Wear your helmet for the P2 belay!

Look for the bolt on the roof down low, this is your line!
P1: 7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor. P2: 6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

Bucket slam! May feel a bit run out between bolts if you're new to outdoor leading or not completely comfortable at the grade.

Straight up from the first (right-most) bolted belay as you walk up Gomer Ledge
6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

climbs.name: Gomer Line
climbs.fa: Scott Jeffries '95 (rebolted on lead by Todd Guy '96)

content.description:
Easy (5.6) jug bashing brings you to a technical crux just after the last bolt. The crux is well protected.

The first bolt line as you go up the Gomer ledge (right-most on the ledge, no belay bolts).
6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

Each bolt protects an easy boulder problem. This line has lots of relatively unique and cool features, and finishes with the crux coming at your last bolt involving a pinch block and a big dead point.

Farthest right sport line on the wall. Look for the mungey corner that marks the end of Gomer wall, to the left of this there is a mixed line with 2 bolts up high, and a few meters left of this is the present line of bolts.
6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

Thinner face down low leads to bucket slamming with fluid movement until a final traverse under a roof to the left before cutting back up right to the chains over the bulge (crux, well protected)!

Straight up from the second bolted belay from the left end of Gomer Ledge.
6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

Thinner face climbing than most of the other climbs on the wall, with several sections at the grade. The climb goes straight up from the farthest left belay bolts on the Gomer Ledge.

Straight up from the farthest left belay bolts on Gomer Ledge.
9 bolts, 2 bolt anchor
If you are looking for decent 5.9-5.10 climbing this is your wall. It has a distinct belay ledge. You may want a stick clip, can be intimidating to new leaders
